intro: Triainolepis rhynchopetala, commonly known as the mountain hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It is characterized by its showy, pentagonal-shaped flowers that are typically pink or purple in color. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and it thrives in high-altitude environments with cool, moist conditions. It is often found growing in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand strong winds and low temperatures. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists alike.
